Graphical abstract An Ag/MgO/ γ -Al2O3 catalyst is developed, which can perform the dual role of a passive NOx adsorber (PNA) at low temperatures and a NOx reduction catalyst at higher temperatures. The effect of H2O and CO2, as well as various reductants such as H2, NH3, and C3H6 on its deNOx performance is investigated. The NOx storage is comparable to that obtained by Pd-based PNAs, and occurs through a spillover mechanism. The presence of H2 remarkably increases the low-temperature NOx adsorption and binding strength, and is attributed to the significant formation of nitrates as opposed to the predominant formation of nitrites in the absence of H2. Moreover, the positive effect of H2 is not related to the H2-SCR activity of the catalyst or an enhancement in the NO oxidation activity. C3H6 inhibits NOx storage, but the presence of H2 promotes it considerably. A significantly high NH3-SCR activity with negligible N2O formation is measured at 150 °C, while C3H6-SCR activity is exhibited at higher temperatures. However, the presence of NH3 does not affect the binding of NOx on the various adsorption sites, which is primarily governed by the presence of H2. However, lean-burn engines operate at lower combustion temperatures and produce high amounts of unburnt hydrocarbons and CO, besides NOx [2]. Various aftertreatment devices consisting of a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) catalyst or a Lean NOx Trap (LNT) can reduce the NOx emissions. However, they operate efficiently only above a minimum temperature. For instance, the negligible hydrolysis of urea to produce ammonia at temperatures less than 180 °C limits the use of SCR technology [3,4]. Similarly, the LNT catalyst can store NOx at low temperatures during lean conditions but cannot effectively reduce the incoming and stored NOx under these conditions. Hence, the future aftertreatment systems need to operate over a wide temperature range, with a specific focus on low-temperature emissions. Passive NOx adsorbers (PNAs) are being investigated by various research groups to address the low-temperature NOx emissions. The principle behind the working of a PNA is to capture NOx at low temperatures and desorb it at temperatures higher than ∼200 °C so that a downstream catalyst such as LNT or SCR can reduce NOx [3,5]. Based on this concept, various catalytic systems combining PNAs and SCRs have been proposed [6,7]. The concept of a PNA was conceived in 1997 in which Cr2O3 dispersed over alumina was placed upstream of a three-way catalyst [8]. In recent years, there has been a renewed research interest to unveil new PNA materials, which can adsorb as well as desorb NOx in the desired temperature range. Most of the PNA materials include Pt and Pd as the active metal(s), and Pd has been found to be the most suitable [5,9–13]. These PNA configurations have a high PGM loading (up to 200 g/ft3), which makes these adsorber materials costly [14]. However, there are only a limited number of studies on the development of non-PGM PNA materials. Tamm et al. [1] explored the use of Ag as a NOx storage material; however, at temperatures higher than 150 °C and high Ag loadings (16 wt%). Tsukamoto et al. [15] incorporated TiO2 into Ag/Al2O3, which resulted in an increase in the low-temperature NOx adsorption. The low-temperature NOx adsorption activity of Ag/Al2O3 was also reported by Ren et al. [14]. Jiang et al. [16] recently developed a Co-SSZ-13 PNA and claimed it to be the first non-precious metal PNA. Non-PGM-based catalytic ‘systems’ have also been developed to reduce the NOx emissions for a range of operating conditions while keeping the catalyst costs low. Selleri et al. [17] proposed the PGM-free AdSCR system, which is based on the combination of a conventional catalyst for NH3-SCR and a NOx storage material such as BaO. However, Ag-based catalysts have not been explored for their dual role as a PNA at low temperatures and as a SCR catalyst at high temperatures. An important aspect related to the functioning of a PNA is the presence of various exhaust gas components such as H2O and CO2, and potential reductants such as H2, CO, and unburnt hydrocarbons (HCs) [3]. Jones et al. [12] prepared Pt and Pd-based PNAs supported on ceria and found an inhibitive effect of CO2 and H2O on NOx storage. Similar results were reported on Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/La-Al2O3 [11]. Theis and Lambert [18] found that the presence of C2H4 and CO increased the NOx storage of a Pd/ceria-zirconia PNA, even in the presence of H2O. The amount of NO adsorbed on Pd/BEA was reported to increase by the addition of CO to the feed [5]. Similar results were observed for three different PNAs with Pd supported on beta, ZSM-5, and SSZ-13 [19]. However, the effect of the co-presence of reductants such as H2, C3H6, and NH3 on the low-temperature NOx storage activity of a Ag-based PNA is not reported, even though the effect of H2 on the HC-SCR and NH3-SCR activity of a Ag/Al2O3 catalyst is well documented [14,20–24]. In this work, an Ag/MgO/ γ -Al2O3 catalyst is developed that possesses NOx adsorption capacity at low temperatures (103 °C), while also exhibiting considerable activity for NO oxidation, HC-SCR, and NH3-SCR at intermediate to high temperatures. The effect of different reductants such as H2, NH3, and C3H6 on the NOx adsorption, desorption, and reduction behavior of the developed catalyst is studied for a wide temperature range. Additionally, the effect of H2O and CO2 on the low-temperature NOx adsorption activity of the catalyst is studied. Various experiments, including isothermal adsorption, temperature-programmed desorption, reactant flow variation, and nearly steady-state experiments are performed to decouple the storage/reaction phenomena and obtain mechanistic insights. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation A 4 wt% Ag catalyst supported on MgO/ γ -Al2O3 was prepared via the incipient wetness impregnation technique. The precursor material with MgO: γ -Al2O3 = 5:95 wt% (PURAL MG05, SASOL) was calcined in static air at 650 °C for 3 h and further used as the support. The resultant calcined powder was impregnated with an aqueous solution of Silver nitrate (Fisher Scientific: CAS-7761−88-8) to yield Ag dispersed over MgO/ γ -Al2O3. The impregnated powder was dried at 110 °C for 5 h and calcined in static air at 550 °C for 3 h. The resultant catalyst is referred to as Ag/Mg-Al in this work, whereas the support MgO/ γ -Al2O3 is referred to as Mg-Al. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area and pore volume of the support and the freshly prepared catalyst were measured using a Micromeritics make 3Flex instrument. Prior to analysis, the samples were degassed in vacuum at 350 °C for two hours to ensure removal of any adsorbed species. XRD was employed to investigate the phases present and the crystallinity of the prepared catalyst. The powdered samples were analyzed at 40 kV and 15 mA, using Miniflex 300/600 under continuous scan mode. The samples were analyzed at a scan speed of 3°/min and step width of 0.02°. For TEM measurements, a colloidal solution consisting of the catalyst sample in isopropanol was sonicated for 15 min. The sonicated sample was dispersed over carbon films on 200 mesh Copper grids. The HR-TEM and TEM images were obtained using TECNAI G2 20 microscope and JEOL JEM-1400 microscope with a maximum accelerating voltage of 200 and 120 kV, respectively. Fiji software was used to obtain the size distribution of the Ag nanoparticles. 2.3 Reactor experiments 2.3.1 Experimental setup The experiments were performed using the reactor setup shown in Fig. 1 . The reactor setup consisted of three sections, namely the gas-supply section, the reactor section, and the gas analysis section. A synthetic mixture of gases was supplied to the reactor section, which contained the catalyst kept in a packed-bed arrangement inside a horizontal quartz tube. The quartz tube was placed inside a temperature-controlled electric furnace (ATS, 1020 W). The packed bed was supported inside the quartz tube using quartz wool. Two K-type thermocouples (Watlow) installed near the inlet and outlet of the packed-bed were used to monitor the temperature continuously. Another K-type thermocouple touching the outer wall of the quartz tube was used to set the temperature. To replicate real-exhaust conditions, H2O and CO2 were always present in the feed stream except for some experiments where the effect of H2O and CO2 on the NOx adsorption characteristics was studied. Additionally, some experiments with different combinations of reductants were done in the absence of CO2. H2O was injected using a continuous double-acting syringe pump (Cole-Parmer, 74905−56). A bypass line was used to stabilize the flow of various gases. All the reactor lines were heated to prevent the condensation of gases. The gases at the outlet of the reactor were continuously monitored with an online FT-IR (MKS, Model 2030). The data was collected every 1 s, which was obtained using a scan rate of four scans per second and a resolution of 0.5 cm −1. For each experiment, the desired composition of the gaseous mixture was obtained in the bypass line. The gases were then diverted to the reactor line, which contained 110 mg catalyst present in the quartz tube. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst was pre-conditioned at 550 °C with a gaseous mixture of 12% O2, 6% H2O, and 6% CO2 balanced in N2 for one hour. For a few experiments where the effect of H2O and CO2 was analyzed, the gas composition for pre-conditioning was dependent on the feed composition for that particular experiment. As an instance, the pre-conditioning gas mixture for the adsorption-desorption experiments without CO2 contained 12% O2, 6% H2O, and balance N2, but did not contain CO2. Similarly, for the adsorption-desorption experiments without H2O, the pre-conditioning gas mixture contained 12% O2 and 6% CO2 balanced in N2. A flow rate of 200 sccm was maintained during all the experiments, which corresponds to a GHSV of 1.09 × 105 cc/g catalyst-hr. 2.3.2 NOx adsorption-desorption After the pre-conditioning, the catalyst was cooled down to the desired temperature under N2 flow. The NOx adsorption-desorption experiments were performed using a gaseous mixture of NO (183 ppm), O2 (10% v/v), CO2 (6% v/v, if present), H2O (6% v/v, if present), C3H6 (500 ppm, if present along with H2 and 550 ppm, if present as the only reductant), H2 (725 ppm, if present), NH3 (237 ppm, if present), and balance N2. Some NO2 was present as an impurity in the NO cylinder and was measured as 13 ppm under these conditions. Thus, the feed mixture contained 170 ppm NO and 13 ppm NO2 but has been mentioned as 183 ppm NO throughout the text for consistency. Independent adsorption experiments were carried out for 220 s at three different temperatures, viz. 103 °C, 115 °C, and 129 °C, which were maintained at a fixed value during the adsorption phase. For all three experiments, the adsorption phase was followed by a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min till a temperature of 495 °C was achieved. The flow of the gas mixture continued until all the concentrations reached steady values at 495 °C. An adsorption-desorption experiment was also carried out over the Mg-Al support for an initial adsorption temperature of 115 °C. Note that even though these experiments are referred to as adsorption-desorption experiments, a small amount of NOx reduction could also take place, the details of which will be discussed later in Sections 3.6-3.8. For some experiments, the adsorption-desorption cycles were repeated. On the completion of each adsorption-desorption cycle, the catalyst bed was conditioned with 12% O2, 6% CO2, and 6% H2O balanced in N2 at 550 °C for 10 min. As discussed in Section 2.3.1, the gas composition during catalyst conditioning for the experiments without H2O or CO2 was dependent on the feed composition for that particular experiment. After the conditioning, the catalyst bed was allowed to cool down in the presence of flowing N2 to the desired adsorption temperature. The amount of NOx adsorbed on a catalyst mass basis was calculated using Eq. (1), where N N O x represents the total moles of NOx adsorbed per gram of the catalyst, ∫ 0 t ϑ ˙ N O x i n d t ' represents the total moles of NOx fed into the reactor till time t , ∫ 0 t ϑ ˙ N O x o u t d t ' represents the total moles of NOx at the reactor outlet till time t, and m is the mass of the catalyst. The NOx concentration at the inlet was obtained by measuring the temporal NOx concentration profile at the outlet of a packed-bed made of quartz particles having the same mass as that of the catalyst. (1) N N O x = ∫ 0 t ϑ ˙ N O x i n d t ' - ∫ 0 t ϑ ˙ N O x o u t d t ' m In various experiments, the steady-state NOx concentration at the reactor outlet was less than that at the inlet, thus indicating the NOx reduction ability of the catalyst in addition to the adsorption of NOx. During transient conditions, a distinction between adsorption or reduction could not be made. Hence, the cumulative NOx adsorption and reduction efficiency was calculated as (2) η = ∫ 0 t N O x i n d t ' - ∫ 0 t N O x o u t d t ' ∫ 0 t N O x i n d t ' × 100 2.3.3 Effect of H2 The effect of the presence of H2 in the feed stream on the NOx adsorption-desorption behavior was examined by switching the flow of H2 on and off for a fixed duration, as explained next. A gaseous mixture consisting of 183 ppm NO, 725 ppm H2, 6% CO2, 6% H2O, 10% O2, and balance N2 was passed over the catalyst at 115 °C. The gases were allowed to flow through the packed-bed for 120 s, after which the flow of H2 was reduced to zero for 120 s. This was again followed by the inclusion of 725 ppm H2 in the feed stream. The total flow rate of the feed stream during the inclusion/exclusion of H2 was kept constant at 200 sccm by changing the flow rate of N2. 2.3.4 NO oxidation To decouple the NO oxidation and NOx storage activity, steady-state experiments were done, and the activity of the catalyst towards NO oxidation was measured. These experiments could show if NO oxidation contributes to the low-temperature adsorption of NO. The catalyst was first saturated with NO at 115 °C using a gas feed comprising of 183 ppm NO, 725 ppm H2, 6% CO2, 6% H2O, 10% O2, and balance N2. Thereafter, the temperature was increased at a slow rate of 1 °C/min so that nearly steady-state conditions could be maintained. The slow temperature ramp continued till a temperature of 240 °C was attained. 2.3.5 NOx temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments The adsorption-desorption experiments described in Section 2.3.2 were performed with a fixed-temperature period of 220 s, during which the catalyst could not be saturated with NOx. Thus, temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) studies were also performed, with the temperature ramp given only after the catalyst was completely saturated with NOx. The experiments were done both in the presence and absence of H2 in the feed. The catalyst was first saturated with NOx at 115 °C by using a gas mixture comprising 183 ppm NO, 725 ppm H2 (if present), 10% O2, and balance N2. Thereafter, the supply of H2 (if present) and NOx was stopped, and the catalyst was purged with a mixture of 12% O2 in N2 to remove the weakly adsorbed NOx species from the surface of the catalyst. This was continued until the outlet NOx concentrations became less than 10 ppm, following which the temperature was ramped up from 115 °C to 550 °C at 10 °C/min. 2.3.6 Effect of H2O and CO2 The low-temperature NOx adsorption activity of various PNAs has been reported to be affected by the presence of H2O and CO2 in the feed [3,12,25]. Thus, adsorption-desorption experiments with and without including H2O and CO2 in the feed were conducted to study their effect on the NOx adsorption-desorption characteristics. The experimental procedure was similar to that described in Section 2.3.2, except for the adsorption period, which was kept at a higher value of 475 s to clearly observe the differences for various gas compositions. The gas mixture for these experiments included 183 ppm NO, 725 ppm H2, 10% O2, 6% CO2 (if present), 6% H2O (if present), and balance N2. 2.3.7 Effect of C3H6 and NH3 In several studies, propylene is used as a representative for unburnt hydrocarbons present in the diesel exhaust, and its role as a NOx reductant has been highlighted [26–30]. Hence, experiments were carried out to study the effect of C3H6 on the NOx adsorption-desorption behavior. The gaseous mixture containing 183 ppm NO, 725 ppm H2, 500 ppm C3H6, 6% CO2, 6% H2O, 10% O2, and balance N2 was used. In these experiments, the formation of NH3 was observed at high temperatures. Since NH3 itself could act as the reductant, the same set of experiments was done with NH3 in the feed stream. For these experiments, the gaseous mixture contained 183 ppm NO, 725 ppm H2, 237 ppm NH3, 6% CO2, 6% H2O, 10% O2, and balance N2. Experiments with 550 ppm C3H6 in the feed were also performed in the absence of H2 to specifically study its role in NOx adsorption/desorption and reduction. Additionally, experiments with different combinations of the reductants were carried out using a feed consisting of 183 ppm NO, 725 ppm H2 (if present), 455 ppm C3H6 (if present), 237 ppm NH3 (if present), 10% O2, 6% H2O, and balance N2. These experiments were performed in the absence of CO2 due to limitations of the setup with respect to the maximum number of gas lines. 2.3.8 NH3-SCR Since the catalyst was found to be active for NOx storage as well as NOx reduction in the presence of NH3, experiments were performed to decouple the two. A gaseous mixture with a flow rate of 200 sccm and consisting of 183 ppm NO, 725 ppm H2, 237 ppm NH3, 6% CO2, 6% H2O, 10% O2, and balance N2 was passed over the catalyst at 150 °C for nearly two hours so that steady-state conditions could be achieved. This enabled the removal of the effect of NOx storage on the measured profiles, and the steady-state NH3-SCR activity could thus be measured. This was followed by a slow temperature ramp of 0.5 °C/min to maintain nearly steady-state conditions. The N2 selectivity ( S N 2 ) at any time instant during the slow temperature ramp was calculated using Eq. (3) as (3) S N 2 = N 2 o u t - N 2 i n N O x i n - N O x o u t + N H 3 i n - N H 3 o u t × 100 where N 2 o u t - N 2 i n was calculated by applying a mole balance on N. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The measured BET surface area of the Mg-Al support and Ag/Mg-Al catalyst was 255 m2/g and 228 m2/g, respectively, whereas the pore volume was 0.59 cm3/g and 0.54 cm3/g, respectively. The slight decrease in BET surface area and the pore volume can be ascribed to the impregnation of Ag over the support. The TEM images of the catalyst samples in Figs. 2 (a) and (b) at two different magnifications show the presence of Ag particles on the support. The size distribution of Ag particles was estimated from these images using Fiji software, and is shown in Figure S1 (Supplementary Information). The Ag particles were found to be in the range of 5−14 nm. The magnified HR-TEM images of two Ag particles are shown in Figure S2 (Supplementary Information), and were used to calculate the distance between the fringes. A spacing of 0.23 nm was found for various fringes and particles, which corresponds to Ag0 (111) [31]. XRD was used to detect any changes in the crystalline phases due to calcination and impregnation of the active metal. The XRD patterns of the Mg-Al support calcined at 650 °C along with the catalyst (Ag/Mg-Al) are shown in Fig. 3 . The diffraction peaks for the support at 2θ values of 19.9°, 33.1°, 37.62°, 46.395°, 61.84°, and 67.243°, respectively correspond to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) planes of γ -Al2O3 (JCPDS card no. 10-0425) [32]. The diffraction pattern of the fresh catalyst revealed a decrease in the intensity of the peaks corresponding to the (311), (400), (511), and (440) planes. Since the amount of MgO in the support material was much less compared to γ -Al2O3, peaks corresponding to MgO were not detected. Apart from the support, no diffraction peaks were observed for Ag either in the metallic or in the oxide form. This is because of its high dispersion on the support, as observed from the TEM images in Fig. 2 and the size distribution in Figure S1 (Supplementary Information). As discussed in an earlier work, the inclusion of MgO in the support contributes towards a reduction in the Ag particle size, thus increasing the Ag dispersion [33]. 3.2 NOx adsorption-desorption The NOx adsorption-desorption behavior was studied in the presence of H2 for three different ‘initial’ temperatures. To check the reproducibility of the experiments, the adsorption-desorption cycles were repeated using the methodology given in Section 2.3.2. The NOx concentration profile during three consecutive NOx adsorption-desorption cycles performed at the initial adsorption temperature (IAT) of 103 °C is shown in Fig. 4 (a). The NOx concentration profiles were nearly the same for the second and third cycles, thus highlighting the nearly complete regeneration of the catalyst and the reproducibility of the results. The developed catalyst was able to capture NOx at low temperatures, as inferred from the lower outlet NOx concentration as compared to the inlet values. The NOx concentration increased in the temperature range of ∼125−145 °C. However, with a further increase in the temperature, there was a decrease in the NOx concentration before increasing again, thus resulting in a shallow minimum. This is possibly due to the presence of another type of NOx adsorption site, which is active to store NOx at temperatures higher than ∼145 °C. A second NOx adsorption minimum was also present in other experiments performed at higher initial adsorption temperatures of 115 °C and 129 °C, as shown in Fig. 4 (b) and (c), respectively. Moreover, the temperature at which the minimum in the NOx concentration occurred was similar (167 °C, 167 °C, and 160 °C), thus highlighting that the same NOx storage site is active for the three different initial adsorption temperatures. It could be argued that the decrease in NOx concentration beyond ∼145 °C is due to the desorption of H2O at these temperatures, resulting in the availability of more sites for NOx adsorption [25]. However, a similar decrease in the NOx concentration was observed even with experiments done in the absence of H2O and CO2, as described later in Section 3.5. Thus, the additional NOx adsorption in the range of ∼145−170 °C is due to the presence of another adsorption site with a different binding strength. We will return to this discussion of the additional adsorption site later in this section, as well as in Section 3.5. In addition to the temporal NOx concentration trends on Ag/Mg-Al, the NOx concentration profile during the adsorption-desorption experiments on the Mg-Al support is shown in Fig. 4 (b). It is clear that the absence of Ag results in a much lower NOx adsorption at low temperatures. Moreover, the outlet NOx concentration becomes higher than the inlet NOx concentration at lower temperatures (170 °C) as compared to ∼210 °C with Ag/Mg-Al. Additionally, the NOx desorption peak with Ag/Mg-Al occurred at much higher temperatures (∼420 °C) as compared to ∼225 °C with Mg-Al, thus indicating the lower NOx binding strength on the standalone support. The temporal NOx concentration profile during the temperature ramp for various initial adsorption temperatures is plotted in Figure S3 (Supplementary Information) for the Ag/Mg-Al catalyst. These curves are plotted with respect to the inlet temperature to see any effect of the initial adsorption temperature on the NOx desorption profiles. For all the three initial adsorption temperatures, the NOx concentration at the reactor outlet was found to exceed the inlet NOx concentration only above ∼210 °C. With an increase in the temperature, NOx desorption took place over a broad temperature range with a nearly constant concentration at the outlet. A sharp NOx desorption peak in the range of 420−430 °C occurred for all the three initial adsorption temperatures. Thus, the initial adsorption temperature did not have a significant effect on the NOx desorption profile. It should also be noted that the outlet NOx concentration at the end of the experiment was nearly the same for various initial adsorption temperatures, thus highlighting the reproducibility of the experiments. It is observed from Fig. 4 that for all the three initial adsorption temperatures, the NOx concentration at the end of the experiment is slightly lower than the inlet NOx concentration, and is attributed to a small H2-SCR activity of the catalyst at high temperatures. In contrast, the Mg-Al support does not exhibit any H2-SCR activity, and the outlet NOx concentration is the same as the inlet NOx concentration at high temperatures under steady-state conditions (Fig. 4 (b)). Assuming negligible NOx reduction in the low-temperature regime, the amount of NOx adsorbed was calculated using Eq. (1) for various initial adsorption temperatures and times, and is given in Table 1 for the Mg-Al support and the Ag/Mg-Al catalyst. The time of 220 s corresponds to the period when the inlet temperature was maintained at a fixed value. The amount of NOx adsorbed at all times is much higher on Ag/Mg-Al as compared to Mg-Al. This could either be due to the availability of Ag sites for NOx storage or the role of Ag in promoting NOx storage over the support. This is discussed later in this section. For a fixed time of exposure, the amount of NOx adsorbed on Ag/Mg-Al increased with the initial adsorption temperature (IAT) and can be attributed to the increase in adsorption rate with temperature. Even though the difference between NOx adsorbed for IAT of 115 °C and 129 °C was negligible at early times, the NOx adsorbed was relatively higher for IAT = 129 °C as compared to the other two temperatures at t = 500 s. This is explained by the presence of another adsorption site, due to which a minimum in NOx concentration was observed in the temperature range of 160−170 °C for the three different initial adsorption temperatures. The inlet temperature reached 160 °C within 500 s for the IAT of 129 °C, but not for 103 and 115 °C, due to which a higher amount of NOx was adsorbed for the IAT of 129 °C. The cumulative NOx adsorption and reduction efficiency ( η ) for the three initial temperatures of 103, 115, and 129 °C for the first 500 s was calculated using Eq. (2) to be 75%, 78%, and 85%, respectively. A comparison was also made for the amount of NOx stored till a particular temperature is reached while starting from different initial temperatures. The NOx adsorption during the time period when the temperature is less than 200 °C was calculated to be 131.1, 125.7, and 120.0 μmol/g for the IAT of 103 °C, 115 °C, and 129 °C, respectively. The decrease in NOx adsorbed with an increase in IAT can be ascribed to the decrease in time duration available for NOx adsorption. The amount of feed NOx also decreased with an increase in IAT due to the lower time taken to reach 200 °C. Several PNAs with different compositions have been reported by various research groups. Since the experimental conditions for GHSV, adsorption temperature, ramp rates, gas compositions, adsorption times, etc. are not the same in various research works, a direct comparison of NOx storage amounts is difficult. However, the results from a few publications are summarized below to indicate that the amount of NOx adsorption achieved in this work with the Ag/Mg-Al catalyst is similar to that obtained by using Pd-based PNAs. Vu et al. [5] reported a NOx adsorption capacity of 20 μmol/g with 1 wt% Pd/BEA for an adsorption time of 100 s at 80 °C. Recently, Gupta et al. [34] investigated Pd/SSZ-13 washcoated over monolithic substrates and reported NO uptake of 100 μmol/g and 110 μmol/g at the adsorption temperatures of 100 °C and 130 °C, respectively, however for a considerably higher adsorption time of 30 min and a GHSV of 30,000 h−1. Zheng et al. [19] investigated Pd-based zeolitic materials as passive NOx adsorbers and reported the highest NOx storage of 1.33 × 10−5 mol (corresponding to 110.8 μmol/g) for a storage time of 10 min at 100 °C and a GHSV of 100,000 h−1. On comparing these numbers with those given in Table 1, it is seen that the amount of NOx adsorbed on the Ag/Mg-Al catalyst is similar to that obtained on the Pd-based PNAs. Further, an experiment was also done with higher initial adsorption times (Fig. 6), which resulted in a significantly high NOx adsorption capacity of 474 μmol/g in 135 min. The product distribution of N-containing species for the last cycle of the NOx adsorption-desorption experiments over the Ag/Mg-Al catalyst is plotted in Fig. 5 for the three initial adsorption temperatures. The formation of NH3 and N2O was negligible throughout the NOx adsorption-desorption cycle. It is known that the formation of N2O takes place with the breaking of NO bonds resulting in adsorbed N and O. The adsorbed N further reacts with adsorbed NO to form N2O [35]. Similarly, the formation of NH3 occurs by the interaction of adsorbed N and H. The non-occurrence of N2O and NH3 in the product, however with a small H2-SCR activity (Fig. 4), indicates that only a small amount of NO gets dissociated under these conditions. The NO and NO2 concentration profiles for various initial adsorption temperatures are plotted together in Figure S4 (Supplementary Information). These curves are plotted with respect to the inlet temperature to see any effect of the initial adsorption temperature on the NOx distribution profiles. The product distribution remained nearly the same for the three initial adsorption temperatures. Hence, only the data from one of the figures (Fig. 5 (b)) is discussed subsequently, and it can be assumed that any such discussion is applicable to Fig. 5 (a) and (c) as well. NO2 was not present in the feed except for that present in the NO cylinder as an impurity, which resulted in 13 ppm NO2 at the catalyst inlet. However, NO2 concentrations higher than 13 ppm were measured for temperatures greater than ∼130 °C (Fig. 5(b)), which indicated the formation of NO2. However, the source of NO2 could not be ascertained from the data of Fig. 5, and it was also not clear if the formation of NO2 is essential for NOx storage. The presence of NO2 could be due to the NO oxidation activity of the catalyst. Furthermore, the NOx adsorbed at low temperatures in the form of nitrites/nitrates could also release NO2 into the gas phase. A combination of these two reasons could also result in the formation of NO2. Experiments on Ag/MgO/ γ -Al2O3 reported elsewhere showed that the NOx adsorption-desorption features were nearly the same with either NO or NO2 in the feed, and was interpreted to be due to the facile formation of nitrates from nitrites [33]. Another possible reason for this observation could be the fast kinetics of NO oxidation on Ag/Mg-Al to form NO2, due to which the NOx adsorption-desorption features would be independent of the presence of NO or NO2 in the feed. To find the extent of contribution of NO oxidation to NOx adsorption, the activity of the catalyst for NO oxidation was determined by performing the experiments described in Section 2.3.4. The gaseous mixture containing NO was passed over the catalyst at 115 °C until the NOx concentration became nearly constant (∼135 min). As shown in Fig. 6, the outlet NO2 concentration was 20 ppm at this time, which is higher than the inlet NO2 concentration (13 ppm). This shows that the catalyst is active for NO oxidation at such low temperatures. However, the amount of NO2 formed is quite low and cannot explain the significant NOx storage at these temperatures. Thus, the formation of NO2 by NO oxidation is not essential for NOx adsorption on Ag/Mg-Al, particularly at low temperatures. We will discuss this point in Section 3.3 as well. For the fixed-temperature period of 135 min, the ratio of moles of NOx stored and the available moles of Ag (assuming 50% Ag dispersion) was calculated to be 5.12. This shows that a considerable amount of NOx adsorption takes place on the support. However, it was shown in Fig. 4 (b) and Table 1 that NOx adsorption over Mg-Al is significantly lower than Ag/Mg-Al, i.e., NOx adsorption takes place on the support only in the presence of Ag. This clearly shows that the adsorption of NOx on the support occurs by spillover through Ag. A closer look at Fig. 6 shows a maximum in NO2 concentration with time for the fixed temperature period. In the presence of H2, the presence of nitrites/nitrates on Ag/Al2O3 has been reported by various researchers [14,36,37]. Moreover, the facile formation of nitrates in the presence of H2 has been hypothesized [33]. Thus, the release of NO2 at early times could be due to the initial storage of NOx in the form of nitrites/nitrates with a minor contribution from NO oxidation. As the catalyst became saturated with NOx, the NO2 production from stored NOx reduced to zero, thus explaining the observed decrease in NO2 concentration during the fixed temperature period. To summarize, the contribution of NO oxidation towards NOx storage and NO2 formation is minimal at low temperatures. The NOx storage could be in the form of nitrites/nitrates, which then release NO2. This point is discussed in more detail in the next paragraph, whereas the possible formation of nitrites and nitrates is discussed in Section 3.4. After the catalyst was nearly saturated with NOx, the temperature was increased beyond 115 °C at a slow rate of 1 °C/min. With an increase in the temperature, the NO2 concentration increased, which was accompanied by a decrease in the NO concentration till 240 °C. The slow temperature ramp from 115−240 °C resulted in maintaining nearly steady-state conditions. Also, only a small amount of previously adsorbed NOx was desorbed, due to which the outlet NOx concentration was close to the inlet NOx concentration. For most of the time during the temperature ramp, the amount of NO2 formed was calculated to be more than the difference between the inlet and outlet NOx concentration. Thus, the increase in NO2 concentration with an increase in the temperature is attributed to the NO oxidation activity of the catalyst, which can partially explain the NO2 observed during the temperature ramp of Fig. 5 (b). Also, the NO2 concentration exhibits a maximum at ∼220 °C, which denotes a reduction in the NO oxidation activity at higher temperatures (Fig. 6). However, no such decrease in NO2 formation was observed in Fig. 5 (b) and Figure S4 at this temperature, and a maximum in NO2 concentration occurred at a higher temperature of ∼270 °C. Despite the decrease in NO oxidation activity for temperatures above 220 °C, an increase in NO2 concentration for these temperatures can be explained by an increase in the decomposition rate of stored nitrites/nitrates. A further decrease in NO2 concentration is because of the decrease in NO oxidation rate as well as a reduction in the amount of stored NOx. It is also noticed that if NO2 was produced only by NO oxidation, its concentration would have decreased monotonically with temperature beyond its peak value at 270 °C. However, a further increase in NO2 concentration resulting in the peak at ∼420 °C shows that NO oxidation is not the only pathway for NO2 production, and the peak is attributed to the release of stored NOx in the form of NO2. Thus, the NO2 concentration profile can be reasonably explained by the relative rates of NO oxidation and the decomposition of stored nitrites/nitrates, with the latter dominant at higher temperatures. Based on the analysis of Figs. 4–6 and Figures S3-S4, it is proposed that the adsorption of NO resulting in the formation of nitrites/nitrates is the primary reason for the lower outlet NOx concentration as compared to that at the inlet. With an increase in temperature, the NO oxidation activity of the catalyst increases, which results in a higher formation of NO2. However, at temperatures greater than ∼145 °C, the NO2 formed adsorbs on another site with a different binding strength, which decreases the NO2 concentration, thus resulting in the second NOx adsorption minimum. The adsorption of NO could also occur in this temperature range, as shown by the minimum in NOx concentration at the same temperature even in the absence of H2, where NO oxidation activity is expected to be low (Fig. 7 ). The presence of two different adsorption sites is also supported by the two different NO2 peaks during the temperature ramp (Fig. 5), which were not observed with Mg-Al (Fig. 4(b)). Moreover, as discussed earlier in this section, the ratio of NOx adsorbed and exposed moles of Ag was ∼5, highlighting that significant NOx adsorption takes place on the support. Thus, one of the NOx adsorption sites can be ascribed to the support, whereas the other site is likely to be present on Ag. As discussed earlier, the initial adsorption temperature did not impact the product distribution profiles to an appreciable extent (Figures S3 and S4, Supplementary Information). For instance, the second NOx concentration minimum, which also coincided with the minimum in NO2 concentration, was exhibited in all three cases in a similar temperature range. Moreover, the three peaks in NO2 concentration at ∼145 °C, ∼270 °C, and ∼420 °C were present for all three initial adsorption temperatures. Thus, it is deduced that the initial adsorption temperature did not significantly affect the binding of NOx and its desorption profiles. 3.3 Effect of hydrogen The presence of H2 could impact the formation of nitrites and nitrates on the surface, which could govern the amount as well as the stability of stored NOx [14]. Hence, to study the specific role of H2 in the functioning of the developed catalyst, the NOx adsorption-desorption experiments were also performed without H2 in the feed. The product distribution for these experiments is shown in Fig. 7 for an initial adsorption temperature of 115 °C. On comparing Figs. 7 and 5(b), it is observed that the absence of H2 has a profound effect on the product distribution throughout the experiment. Similar to the experiments with H2 in the feed, N2O and NH3 were not observed at the reactor outlet. However, the outlet NOx concentration during the fixed-temperature regime and during the early temperature ramp was much higher as compared to the H2–containing feed. The amount of NOx adsorbed using the data of Fig. 7 was calculated to be 39.8 μmol/g for the first 500 s, whereas the NOx storage in the presence of H2 was ∼2.2 times at 86.9 μmol/g. Thus, the presence of H2 resulted in a drastic increase in the low-temperature NOx storage. The amount of NOx adsorbed till the temperature reached 200 °C was calculated with and without the presence of H2 in the feed, and is given in Table 2 . It is observed that NOx storage is significantly higher at 125.7 μmol/g with H2 in the feed as compared to 49.8 μmol/g in the absence of any reductant. It could be argued that the higher value of measured NOx adsorption is due to the H2-SCR activity of the catalyst. However, as shown later in Fig. 16, the cumulative NOx reduction efficiency at the end of the experiment was low, suggesting that the H2-SCR activity was minimal. Thus, the higher value of measured NOx ‘adsorption’ in the presence of H2 is not related to the H2-SCR activity of the catalyst. The amount of NOx consumed is given in Table 2 for other reaction conditions as well, and will be discussed later in the subsequent sections. With a nearly flat NOx concentration profile for t<400 s, a shallow minimum in the NOx concentration occurs at ∼155 °C in the absence of any reductant (Fig. 7). A similar decrease in NOx concentration was also observed in the presence of H2 at a slightly higher temperature, and it was reasoned that this is unlikely to be due to the H2-SCR activity. Thus, it is inferred that the presence of H2 increases the binding strength, due to which NOx continues to adsorb at higher temperatures. A similar inference is drawn by comparing the NOx desorption temperatures, a discussion on which is given in Section 3.8. The appearance of NO2 at the reactor outlet in the absence of a reductant is observed to be later than in Fig. 5 (b), which could be due to the lower NO oxidation activity in the absence of H2 [22]. This also indicates that the NOx minimum at 167 °C is primarily due to the adsorption of NO (and not NO2). As the temperature was increased further, a sharp NOx desorption peak appeared at ∼200 °C in the absence of H2 as compared to NOx desorption for a broad range of temperatures in the presence of H2. To further highlight the role of H2 in low-temperature NOx adsorption, the H2 on/off experiments discussed in Section 2.3.3 were performed, and the NOx concentration profile is shown in Fig. 8 . Note that the switching on/off of H2 was earlier than that marked in the figure, and the difference is due to a finite delay in the measurement. For an easy graphical representation, the switching on/off is marked after incorporating the delay. With the introduction of the gaseous mixture containing H2 into the reactor, the NOx concentration decreased with time, which signifies the storage of NOx. Thereafter, the H2 flow was reduced to zero while increasing the flow rate of N2 to maintain the same total volumetric flow rate. Upon switching off the H2 flow, the NOx concentration started to increase, which suggests a decrease in the NOx adsorption rate. To ensure that the increase in NOx concentration was not due to a saturation of the NOx adsorption sites, H2 was again introduced into the reactor. It was observed that the NOx concentration began to decrease again upon the introduction of H2. On repeating the H2 on/off procedure once again, similar observations were made. Thus, this experiment led us to conclude that the presence of H2 in the feed enhances the NOx storage at low temperatures. Other than diesel exhausts which could contain some amount of H2, this result has applications in H2-fuelled internal combustion engines whose exhaust contains both NOx and H2 [38,39]. For NOx storage catalysts such as lean NOx traps, it is known that the rate of NOx storage is higher with NO2 in the feed as compared to NO, and is attributed to the facile formation of nitrates [40]. Due to this, an oxidation catalyst for NO oxidation to NO2 assists the storage of NOx. Even for the Ag/Mg-Al catalyst, the increase in NOx storage with H2 in the feed could be due to the promoting effect of H2 on NO oxidation, which is reported for a Ag/Al2O3 catalyst [14]. However, as discussed in Section 3.2, the catalyst did not exhibit any significant NO oxidation activity at 115 °C in the presence of H2. Thus, at low temperatures, the positive effect of H2 on NOx storage cannot be attributed to the NO oxidation activity of the catalyst. This proposal is consistent with the observation that the NO oxidation activity of the catalyst to form NO2 contributes minimally towards NOx storage, particularly at low temperatures. 3.4 Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments The procedure for the NOx TPD experiments is given in Section 2.3.5, according to which a fixed temperature of 115 °C was maintained until the reactor outlet NOx concentration became equal to the inlet NOx concentration. Subsequent to removing the loosely-adsorbed NOx from the surface, the NOx desorption profiles in the presence and absence of H2 in the feed were captured, and are shown in Fig. 9 . In the absence of H2, two maxima in NOx concentration were observed at ∼175 °C and 475 °C, with a higher amount of NOx desorption at low temperatures. In contrast, in the presence of H2, some amount of NOx desorption took place over a broad temperature range and was followed by a maximum at 440 °C, with most of the NOx getting desorbed at high temperatures. Even though the amount of NOx adsorbed was higher in the presence of H2, the low-temperature NOx desorption (<250 °C) was even lower than the amount desorbed in the absence of H2. By conducting DRIFTS studies on a Ag/Al2O3 catalyst, Ren et al. [14] showed the existence of nitrites as the major NOx species at 150 °C and 200 °C in the absence of H2. The presence of H2 significantly enhanced the formation of nitrates, which are more stable than nitrites. Thus, the higher amount of NOx adsorption and the higher proportion of NOx desorption at high temperatures in the presence of H2 can be explained by the formation of nitrates. In contrast, the higher proportion of NOx desorption at low temperatures in the absence of H2 is attributed to the decomposition of nitrites at these temperatures. These inferences are in agreement with our previous study wherein it is hypothesized that a facile conversion of nitrites to nitrates takes place in the presence of H2 [33]. To summarize, nitrates are likely to be the predominant N-containing species on the catalyst surface in the presence of H2, whereas nitrites would be present in the absence of H2. 3.5 Effect of H2O and CO2 In a previous study on the same catalyst, the occurrence of a second minimum in NOx concentration during the temperature ramp was found to be more pronounced at higher initial adsorption times [33]. Thus, the adsorption-desorption experiments to study the effect of H2O and CO2 were done at higher initial adsorption times of 475 s, and the results are shown in Fig. 10 . The corresponding amount of NOx adsorbed for various feed compositions and times is given in Table 3 . To check the reproducibility, the experiments were repeated and the NOx concentration profiles for two consecutive adsorption-desorption cycles in the absence of H2O are shown in Figure S5 (Supplementary Information). It is observed that the trends are nearly the same, thus ensuring the consistency of the data. On comparing the NOx concentration trends (Fig. 10) and the calculated NOx adsorption with and without the inclusion of CO2 (Table 3), it is clear that CO2 strongly inhibits NOx adsorption and could be due to the formation of carbonates on the surface. On comparing the results obtained with and without H2O, it is seen that the presence of H2O enhanced the adsorption of NOx and resulted in a higher amount of NOx adsorbed at early times (t<200 s). It is conjectured that H2O results in the formation of hydroxyls which enhance NOx adsorption. Interestingly, as time progresses, the positive effect of H2O diminished, and the difference in the NOx adsorption with and without H2O decreased (t<400 s). With further progress in time and an increase in the temperature, the NOx adsorption with H2O was calculated to be lower than that obtained without H2O. When both H2O and CO2 were present in the feed, the NOx adsorption was significantly higher than that obtained with CO2 (without H2O) in the feed and was also more than that obtained in the absence of H2O and CO2. Moreover, the NOx concentration trends at early times were nearly the same as those obtained with H2O (without CO2) in the feed. Thus, the presence of H2O promotes NOx adsorption at early times and diminishes the inhibiting effect of CO2 over NOx adsorption. However, at later times, the co-presence of H2O and CO2 resulted in a lower NOx adsorption as compared to when H2O (without CO2) was present in the feed, and could be related to the inhibitive effect of CO2. A more detailed analysis would be conducted to further understand these interesting results, including performing experiments with different pretreatment conditions. These experiments are expected to explain the change in the effect of H2O on NOx adsorption at different times. The results without H2O and CO2 and those with H2O and CO2 in the feed were compared during the temperature ramp. For both cases, a prominent decrease in the NOx concentration was observed starting at ∼130−135 °C, and a minimum in NOx concentration occurred between 160−170 °C. Thus, the second minimum (also observed for lower NOx adsorption times in Figs. 4 and 5) is due to the presence of a second NOx adsorption site, and cannot be ascribed to the desorption of H2O. 3.6 Effect of C3H6 Two consecutive NOx adsorption-desorption cycles were carried out to study the effect of C3H6 in the feed, and the corresponding NOx concentration profiles are shown in Fig. 11 . For these experiments, H2 was present in the feed in addition to other species. The NOx concentration profiles for the two cycles nearly overlap, thus indicating the reproducibility of the experiment. The entire duration of the experiment was divided into three zones, as detailed next. On comparing with Fig. 4 (b), it is noted that in zone 1, the shape of the NOx concentration curve is similar to that without C3H6. The shallow minimum in NOx concentration, denoting the presence of an additional NOx adsorption site is noticed, a finding which was also made in the absence of C3H6 in the feed. The temperature range in which the outlet NOx concentration is higher than the inlet concentration (zone 2) is much narrower as compared to the case without C3H6. At high temperatures (zone 3), the outlet NOx concentration is lower than the inlet concentration, in contrast to the case when C3H6 was not present in the feed. At the end of the experiment (t = 3000 s), the NOx conversion based on the inlet and outlet NOx concentrations was calculated to be 60%. This suggests an additional role of C3H6 in lowering the NOx concentrations at high temperatures. If C3H6 serves as the NOx reductant, its concentration should also become lower than the inlet values. However, the decrease in C3H6 concentration at such high temperatures could also be due to its oxidation by O2. Hence, the temporal concentration profile of C3H6 was plotted in addition to other product species, and is shown in Fig. 12 . C3H6 concentration remained nearly constant during the initial fixed-temperature period of 220 s (the dip at early times was due to the switch from the bypass to the reactor line). Its concentration decreased monotonically during the temperature ramp and was significantly lowered at high temperatures. The lower C3H6 and NOx concentrations as compared to their inlet values could be partly due to their adsorption. Thomas [22] reported the presence of H2 to promote C3H6 storage in the form of oxidized intermediates (CxHyOz) over Ag/Al2O3 below 250 °C. However, adsorption cannot explain the reduction in concentrations at the high temperatures of zone 3 and the sustained low concentrations once the temperature reaches the maximum value (Fig. 11). This confirms the existence of a SCR pathway on the Ag/Mg-Al catalyst. Thus, the lower outlet NOx concentration as compared to the feed values with C3H6 as the reductant cannot be attributed solely to the adsorption of NOx. This reaffirms the reason for naming ‘η’ as the cumulative ‘adsorption and reduction’ efficiency. The NOx concentration profiles during the adsorption-desorption experiments performed with and without the presence of C3H6 in the feed (which contained H2 in both cases) were plotted on the same curve, and are shown in Fig. 13 . The concentration profiles for other feed compositions are also plotted, but will be discussed later. The NOx concentration trends with ‘H2+C3H6’ and ‘H2’ are similar at low temperatures. Only above a temperature of ∼280 °C did the two curves deviate, and the presence of C3H6 resulted in a lower NOx concentration. This indicates that NOx reduction through the HC-SCR pathway initiates for temperatures greater than ∼280 °C. However, C3H6 concentration was lower than the inlet values even for temperatures less than ∼140 °C (Fig. 12). Thus, C3H6 participates in a reaction other than HC-SCR, the most likely being its adsorption on the catalytic sites and its oxidation by O2 or reforming by H2O [21]. Indirect evidence for the oxidation is the evolution of CO at T>∼230 °C (Fig. 12). At low temperatures, even though C3H6 oxidation by O2 could take place, CO may be adsorbed on the catalyst and hence does not appear at the reactor outlet. Thomas [22] also observed CO at ∼210 °C while performing HC-SCR experiments on a Ag/Al2O3 catalyst in the presence of H2. Moreover, the storage of hydrocarbons in the form of partially oxidized species between 150 and 300 °C was reported [22]. In the co-presence of H2 and C3H6, NH3 and C2H4 were also measured at the reactor outlet for temperatures higher than ∼350 °C, even though the concentrations were less than 15 ppm throughout the experiment (Figure S6, Supplementary Information). Kim et al. [21] also reported the formation of NH3 on Ag/Al2O3 with a mixture of ethanol and simulated diesel fuel as the feed. It is possible that NH3 and C2H4 are formed as intermediates and can also participate in the NOx reduction at intermediate temperatures, due to which their concentrations are low. The curves for NH3 and ethylene concentrations exhibit similar trends, and hence their formation could be related by a common mechanism. NOx adsorption-desorption experiments were also performed in the presence of only C3H6 as the reductant, i.e., without H2 in the feed. Fig. 13 shows that the low-temperature NOx adsorption reduced drastically with C3H6 as the only reductant. As given in Table 2, the adsorbed NOx was calculated to be 33.1 μmol/g till 200 °C, which is even less than the adsorbed amount of 49.8 μmol/g when any reductant was not present in the feed. Thus, the presence of C3H6 inhibits NOx storage at low temperatures, which is possibly due to the inhibition of NOx spillover and is attributed to competitive adsorption, whereas H2 promotes it to such an extent that the inhibitive effect of C3H6 is mitigated in the presence of H2. The product distribution profile with only C3H6 as the reductant is plotted in Figure S7 (Supplementary Information). On comparing with Fig. 12, it is observed that even though C3H6 concentration decreases monotonically with time, the decrease is quite slow for T<∼280 °C, which is the temperature range where C3H6 consumption due to its adsorption or oxidation by O2 occurred in the presence of H2. This shows that C3H6 adsorption/oxidation on Ag/Mg-Al is promoted in the presence of H2. This interpretation is consistent with the direct measurements on a Ag/Al2O3 catalyst, wherein a decrease in activation energy for hydrocarbon oxidation was reported in the presence of H2 [21]. 3.7 Effect of NH3 3.7.1 Adsorption-desorption experiments As discussed in Section 3.6, ammonia formation took place during the NOx adsorption-desorption cycles in the presence of C3H6 and H2 as reductants. However, NH3 formed over the catalyst could itself act as a reductant due to which the actual amount of NH3 formed may be greater than that measured at the outlet. Thus, the NOx adsorption-desorption experiments were also conducted with NH3 in the feed stream in addition to H2, and the measured product distribution is shown in Fig. 14 . Similar to other feed compositions, a shallow minimum in the NOx concentration appeared at ∼115 s, and an increase ensued thereafter. The NOx concentration trends for ‘H2’ and ‘H2+NH3’ were similar at early times (Fig. 13). Thus, the presence of NH3 does not affect the low-temperature NOx adsorption significantly. Moreover, the three NO2 desorption peaks are nearly at the same temperature as that obtained with H2 as the only reductant (Figure S8, Supplementary Information). Thus, the presence of NH3 does not influence the binding of NOx on the various adsorption sites. Unlike the case with H2 or H2+C3H6 as the reductants, the second minimum in NOx concentration was not observed, and the NOx concentration decreased monotonically from ∼155 °C till ∼200 °C. This decrease is attributed to the onset of the NH3-SCR reaction, which is shown to occur at temperatures as low as 150 °C on this catalyst (Section 3.7.2). Low-temperature NH3-SCR has been reported for Ag/Al2O3 as well [23,41,42]. An observation that seems contradictory to the NH3-SCR explanation is the increase in NH3 concentration during this time period, which should have decreased if it was responsible for reducing NOx. To understand this seeming contradiction, the NH3 concentration profiles were analyzed in the low-temperature range. A steep decrease in NH3 concentration occurred till 127 °C, followed by an increase till 195 °C, which indicated adsorption followed by desorption. To confirm if the decrease in NH3 concentration was not due to its sticking on the tube walls, a gas mixture of the same composition was passed over a packed bed made of quartz particles, and the measured NH3 concentrations are marked as ‘NH3 inlet’ in Fig. 14. The lower NH3 concentration as compared to the inlet values shows that the catalyst is active for NH3 adsorption at low temperatures, and the increase in NH3 concentration is because of the desorption of NH3 adsorbed during the constant temperature period. Thus, despite the occurrence of the NH3-SCR reactions, an increase in NH3 concentration until 195 °C could be explained by the dominance of NH3 desorption as compared to its participation in surface reactions. An important observation is that throughout the experiment, the outlet NOx concentration remained lower than the inlet NOx concentration. Moreover, N2O formation was found to be negligible throughout the experiment, and the catalyst was highly selective towards N2. As shown later in Fig. 16, the cumulative NOx adsorption and reduction efficiency till 300 °C was calculated to be 74.2%, which shows that the catalyst exhibited significant NH3-SCR activity in the typical temperature range of diesel exhaust. Thus, if the present catalyst is placed upstream of a commercial SCR catalyst, it can reduce the metal loading requirements of the downstream SCR catalyst. Also, it can reduce the cold-start NOx emissions due to its NOx adsorption and reduction activity at low temperatures, as can be seen from the low NOx concentrations (< 5 ppm) even at temperatures as low as 180 °C. 3.7.2 Slow temperature-ramp experiments The concentration profiles in Fig. 14 are quite complex with multiple peaks and troughs. Since these experiments are inherently transient in nature, the profiles are dependent on the history as well. As an example, it was discussed in Section 3.7.1 that the NH3-SCR reactions likely take place between ∼155 °C and 200 °C, even though NH3 concentration increased in this time interval, and the observation was attributed to the desorption of previously-stored NH3. It could be argued that the decrease in NOx concentration for these conditions is due to the activation of an additional site, which is active for NOx adsorption under these conditions. It could also be argued that throughout the experiment, the lower NH3 concentration as compared to the inlet concentration is due to its adsorption and not related to the NH3-SCR reaction. Hence, to find if the lower NOx and NH3 concentrations are due to their adsorption on the catalyst or conversion to some other species, it was attempted to decouple the storage and reactions of NH3 and NOx. Nearly steady-state experiments were carried out in which the catalyst was saturated with NOx and NH3 at 150 °C for ∼120 min, followed by a slow temperature ramp of 0.5 °C/min. Even after exposure to NOx for nearly two hours, the NOx concentration at the outlet of the reactor was 39 ppm (Fig. 15 ). This translates to a significantly high 79% NOx conversion at a low temperature of 150 °C. Moreover, after the initial NH3 adsorption period, its concentration reached a steady-state value of ∼110 ppm. Under these conditions, the ratio of moles of NO consumed and NH3 consumed was calculated to be 1.06, which is consistent with the stoichiometry of the standard NH3-SCR reaction given as 4 NO + 4 NH3 + O2 ⟶ 4 N2 + 6 H2O. Thus, the decrease in NOx concentration during ∼155−200 °C in Fig. 14 can be unequivocally attributed to the onset of the NH3-SCR reaction. Using H2 and NH3 as reductants, Richter et al. [42] reported a 15% NOx conversion at 150 °C using a 1 wt% Ag/Al2O3 catalyst and 60% NOx conversion with a 5 wt% Ag/Al2O3 catalyst. Their experiments were performed in the absence of CO2 at a lower space velocity of 3 × 104 cc/g cat-hr as compared to 1.09 × 105 cc/g cat-hr used in this work. Thus, the higher NH3-SCR activity in this work (79% NOx conversion at 150 °C with a 4 wt% Ag/Mg-Al catalyst) could be related to support effects. However, this was not independently verified. With an increase in the temperature, the NH3 and NOx concentrations decreased till ∼195 °C, with a maximum NOx and NH3 conversions of 93% and 68%, respectively. However, high NH3 concentrations exceeding the inlet NH3 concentration were measured at these temperatures during the adsorption-desorption experiments (Fig. 14). This clearly shows that the increase in NH3 concentration for T<∼195 °C during the adsorption-desorption experiments was due to the desorption of previously-stored NH3. On comparing Figs. 14 and 15, it is observed that the steady-state NOx and NH3 concentrations at 495 °C are nearly the same as that obtained at the end of the adsorption-desorption experiment. This shows that a steady state was indeed maintained during the slow temperature-ramp experiments. The N2 selectivity calculated using Eq. (3) was found to be nearly 100% throughout the temperature ramp, since negligible amounts of N2O were measured at the reactor outlet. This shows that the catalyst is highly selective to N2 for a broad range of temperatures. Further, the ratio of the moles of NO consumed and NH3 consumed was calculated at various times, and is given in Figure S9 (Supplementary Information). The ratio was in the range 1–1.1 till ∼300 °C, beyond which it decreased with time. The NO/NH3 consumption ratio near 1 is consistent with the occurrence of the standard-SCR reaction for a range of temperatures. The decrease in ratio beyond ∼300 °C signifies the initiation of the NH3 oxidation reactions to yield NO and N2. Chmielarz et al. [43] also reported NH3 conversion to yield NO, N2O, and N2 on the bare Mg-Al support in the temperature range of 300 °C–450 °C. The occurrence of NH3 oxidation to yield NO and N2 was also reported by Montanari et al. [44] on the Mg-Al support. Even though negligible NO2 was measured at the outlet during slow temperature-ramp experiments (Fig. 15), a finite amount of NO2 was measured under transient conditions in the presence of NH3 (Fig. 14), which indicates that NO2 is formed by the decomposition of stored NOx. This is supported by the observation that the NO2 concentration trends (and not values) in the co-presence of NH3 and H2 were nearly the same as that obtained with H2 as the only reductant (Figure S8, Supplementary Information). This is explained in more detail as follows. A maximum in the NOx concentration occurred during the adsorption-desorption experiments at ∼420 °C (Fig. 14), even though NOx concentration increased monotonically at these temperatures under steady-state conditions (Fig. 15). Given that the maximum in NOx concentration occurred at a similar temperature as that with H2 as the only reductant, this shows that the maximum is due to the desorption of stored NOx. The same argument is valid for other NOx desorption peaks as well. Thus, the higher amount of NO2 in the adsorption-desorption experiment as compared to the steady-state experiment is due to its formation from stored NOx in the form of nitrates. On comparing the NOx concentration profiles with and without the presence of NH3, it can be said that even though the presence of NH3 results in a lower NOx concentration, the trends for NOx concentration are primarily governed by its adsorption-desorption characteristics (Fig. 13), i.e., NH3 does not affect the binding strength of NOx on various adsorption sites. It is also observed from Fig. 15 that the concentration of NO2 is very low for the entire slow temperature-ramp experiment in contrast to the results obtained during the slow temperature-ramp experiments in the absence of NH3 (Fig. 6). This shows that even though NO is oxidized to NO2 in the absence of NH3, it is consumed via the NH3-SCR pathway in the presence of NH3. To summarize, the steady-state experiments with NH3 show that the catalyst is active for NH3-SCR at temperatures as low as 150 °C. By decoupling the storage and reaction phenomenon, the NOx concentration trends obtained during the adsorption-desorption experiments could be explained. 3.8 Effect of different reductants To study the effect of various reductants on the NOx adsorption, desorption, and reduction behavior, a comparison of the NOx concentration profiles for various feed combinations was made (Fig. 13). The amount of NOx adsorbed until the inlet temperature reached 200 °C was also compared using Table 2. As given earlier, NO, O2, H2O, and CO2 were present in the feed for all these experiments. It is observed from Table 2 that the lowest amount of NOx adsorption took place in the presence of only C3H6 as the reductant. On comparing the ‘no reductant’ and ‘C3H6’ feed, it is discerned that C3H6 has an inhibiting effect on the NOx adsorption during the initial temperature ramp period. However, if H2 is added to the feed along with C3H6, the NOx adsorption increases significantly. Moreover, on comparing various NOx concentration profiles (Fig. 13) and NOx adsorption values (Table 2), it is observed that if H2 is present in the feed, the NOx adsorption is higher than that obtained in the absence of H2. This result is independent of whether H2 is present as the only reductant or in combination with NH3 or C3H6. Thus, it is clear that H2 assists the low-temperature NOx storage on Ag/Mg-Al. Moreover, the broad peak in NOx concentration during the temperature ramp in the presence of H2 (either as the only reductant or along with C3H6 or NH3) occurs at a higher temperature than that in its absence (no reductant or C3H6 as the only reductant). Thus, H2 strengthens the binding of NOx on the adsorption sites as well. The NOx concentration profiles with H2, H2+NH3, and H2+C3H6 as the reductants nearly overlap till ∼145 °C. This shows that NH3 and C3H6 have a negligible effect on NOx storage in the presence of H2 under these conditions. The profiles with H2 and H2+C3H6 further overlap till ∼280 °C, which is followed by a decrease in the NOx concentration if C3H6 is present. The decrease is attributed to the onset of HC-SCR reactions, as discussed in Section 3.6. This is supported by the observation that even with C3H6 as the only reductant, the NOx concentration decreased below the inlet value only above this temperature. Thus, with the co-presence of C3H6 and H2 in the feed, Ag/Mg-Al displays PNA activity at low temperatures and HC-SCR activity at high temperatures. However, with H2 as the only reductant, little H2-SCR activity is observed, and NOx continues to desorb as the temperatures are increased beyond 280 °C. Even though the presence of C3H6 in the feed results in NOx reduction, however, a considerable activity is measured only at high temperatures. In contrast, the presence of NH3 initiates the NOx reduction at much lower temperatures, as inferred by comparing the NOx concentration profiles with H2 and H2+NH3 as reductants. Except for the initial overlap till ∼145 °C, the NOx concentrations in the co-presence of H2 and NH3 are considerably lower than the concentrations measured with H2 as the only reductant. Remarkably, the NOx concentrations are less than 10 ppm, even for low temperatures in the range of ∼165−210 °C. This low-temperature NH3-SCR activity results in the highest amount of NOx consumption in the cold-start region using H2+NH3 as the reductants (Table 2). Figure S8 shows that with H2+C3H6 as the reductants, the first two NO2 desorption peaks are nearly at the same temperature as those obtained with H2 as the only reductant. However, the third NO2 peak does not appear with H2+C3H6, and is attributed to the occurrence of the HC-SCR reaction at high temperatures. On the other hand, even though the catalyst exhibits NH3-SCR activity (Fig. 14), the NO2 desorption peaks with H2+NH3 occur at nearly the same temperature as with H2 as the only reductant. As discussed in Section 3.7.2, this indicates that even though NH3 reduces NOx thereby decreasing its concentration, the binding strength of NOx on various adsorption sites is not altered in the presence of NH3. A similar observation was made for H2+C3H6, except for the non-occurrence of the NOx desorption peak at high temperatures (420 °C). Thus, it is concluded that H2 primarily governs the NOx binding strength, which also results in similar shapes of the NOx concentration curves for various reductants. The differences in the NOx concentration profiles, if present, are due to the onset of SCR activity, the temperature of which depends on the reactant (i.e., either NH3 or C3H6). The cumulative NOx adsorption and reduction efficiency during the adsorption-desorption experiments was calculated using Eq. (2) for various reductants, and the results during the temperature ramp are shown in Fig. 16. With H2 or H2+C3H6 in the feed as reductants, the efficiency is more than 70% for temperatures up to ∼210 °C. For H2+NH3, the temperature range with more than 70% efficiency extends up to ∼350 °C. This is attributed to the onset of the NH3-SCR reaction, which also results in a peak NOx efficiency of 85% at 227 °C. With an increase in temperature beyond the point of maximum efficiency, the decrease in efficiency is due to the desorption of NOx. The efficiency curve with C3H6 as the only reductant is the lowest of all cases for a wide range of temperatures, and is attributed to the inhibition of NOx storage by C3H6. At temperatures exceeding ∼280 °C, the catalyst becomes active for HC-SCR, due to which the cumulative efficiency increases with time. The onset of the HC-SCR reaction can also explain the minimum in the efficiency for H2+C3H6. With H2+C3H6 as the reductants, a Nitrogen-balance was done to calculate the amount of N2 formed over the entire adsorption-desorption cycle, and was found to be 128.4 μmol/g, whereas the formation of N2O was negligible. However, small amounts of NH3 were formed and corresponded to 16.1 μmol/g. Thus, the catalyst is highly selective towards N2 formation throughout the temperature range. A similar calculation was done with H2+NH3 in the feed, and the formation of N2 was found to be the highest at 513.5 μmol/g, whereas the formation of N2O was negligible. Moreover, the cumulative efficiency at the end of the experiment was the highest with H2+NH3 at 50% as compared to 41% for H2+C3H6. Additional experiments were performed for various reductant combinations, including the one with all the reductants (H2, C3H6, and NH3) present in the feed. As discussed in Section 2.3.7, these experiments were done in the absence of CO2, and the cumulative efficiency is shown in Figure S10 (Supplementary Information). The cumulative efficiency with the co-presence of H2, NH3, and C3H6 in the feed was 84% for the complete cycle, which was the highest amongst all the reductant combinations. Thus, Ag/MgO/ γ -Al2O3 can function as a NOx adsorber and a deNOx catalyst for a range of temperatures and gas compositions. It is expected that a PNA would be placed in front of a diesel particulate filter (DPF) and/or an SCR catalyst. Hence, if the PNA generates fast-SCR conditions at the outlet during the temperature ramp (NO2/NOx = 0.5), it would be an added advantage for the downstream SCR catalyst. Moreover, a high amount of NO2 can assist in the passive regeneration of a DPF. Hence, the NO2/NOx ratio was plotted for various feed combinations during the NOx adsorption-desorption experiments, as shown in Fig. 17 . The NO2/NOx ratio for the inlet feed stream was 0.07. Hence, a value above 0.07 indicates NO2 formation either from the stored nitrates or NO oxidation. For the three different combinations of reductants, i.e., H2, H2+C3H6, and H2+NH3, the outlet NOx concentration was ≤ 25 ppm for T<∼165 °C, and the NO2/NOx ratio may not influence the activity of the downstream aftertreatment devices significantly under these conditions. However, at higher NOx concentrations, this ratio can impact the performance of the downstream catalysts or the particulate filter. With H2 as the only reductant, the NO2/NOx ratio was more than 0.5 in a wide temperature range of ∼135−455 °C. Thus, the majority of the NOx desorbed from the catalyst surface is in the form of NO2, which was also evident from the product distribution curve given in Fig. 5 (b). The trends for NO2/NOx ratio with H2+NH3 are nearly similar to those obtained with H2, and the temperature range where NO2/NOx ratio is more than 0.5 is only slightly wider as compared to that obtained with H2. However, NO2/NOx ratio was higher than 0.5 in a relatively narrow range of 140−375 °C with H2+C3H6, and the decrease in NO2/NOx ratio with temperature beyond ∼280 °C is due to the onset of the HC-SCR reaction (Section 3.6). 4 Conclusions An Ag/MgO/ γ -Al2O3 catalyst is developed, which shows the potential as a passive NOx adsorber at low temperatures and a NH3-SCR and HC-SCR catalyst at intermediate to high temperatures. Various experiments such as fixed-temperature adsorption, temperature-programmed desorption, reactant on/off studies, and nearly steady-state experiments were performed to investigate the effect of gas composition on the deNOx performance of the catalyst. A comparison of the amount of Ag and adsorbed NOx shows that significant NOx adsorption occurs on the support through a spillover process involving Ag. Two different NOx adsorption sites having a distinct binding strength exist on the catalyst, which result in the occurrence of a shallow NOx concentration minimum at nearly the same temperature for various initial adsorption temperatures. Two distinct minima in NOx concentration were observed even in the absence of H2O and CO2, highlighting that the second NOx adsorption minimum is not due to the desorption of H2O. The adsorption/desorption profiles of both NO and NO2 did not vary significantly for the various initial temperatures considered in this study, suggesting that the binding strength is not affected by the initial temperature. A slow-temperature ramp experiment showed that at low temperatures, the NO oxidation activity of the catalyst is minimal and hence cannot be the reason for the high amount of NOx storage at these temperatures. A comparison of the adsorption-desorption experiments and the slow temperature-ramp experiments revealed that NO oxidation is not the only pathway for NO2 production, and NO2 is likely released from the stored nitrates/nitrites, especially at higher temperatures. The impact of H2 on NOx adsorption was studied using H2 on/off experiments, and it was found that the presence of H2 increases the low-temperature NOx adsorption significantly, which is attributed to the higher formation of nitrates. Moreover, the presence of H2 strengthens the NOx binding, which is concluded from the higher temperatures of the NOx desorption peak in its presence. Experiments with and without CO2 in the feed showed the inhibitive effect of CO2 on NOx adsorption. H2O increased the NOx adsorption rate at early times, but the amount of NOx adsorbed was lower at later times. NOx TPD studies were used to deduce the formation of nitrite species in the absence of H2 and the presence of relatively stable nitrates in the presence of H2. Studies with C3H6 showed that even though C3H6 inhibits NOx storage considerably, the presence of H2 enhances it to such an extent that the NOx storage with H2 and H2+C3H6 is similar. The presence of C3H6 along with H2 increases the high-temperature NOx reduction via HC-SCR, while also retaining the low-temperature NOx adsorption features. However, the reduction of NOx is not very effective at intermediate temperatures, and C3H6 could either adsorb on the sites or oxidize to form CO and C2H4. The presence of NH3 in the feed was found to be an optimal solution with a peak NOx adsorption and reduction efficiency of 85%, and is attributed to the onset of the NH3-SCR reaction at low temperatures. The occurrence of the NH3-SCR reaction was confirmed by performing steady-state experiments, in which a significantly high 79% NOx conversion at 150 °C and a peak NOx conversion of 93% at 195 °C was measured. The NOx/NH3 consumption ratio was calculated to be nearly one in these experiments, thus suggesting the occurrence of a standard NH3-SCR reaction. Since the steady-state NH3-SCR activity was measured in the absence of any storage/release effects, it could explain the complex trends during the adsorption-desorption experiments, which involved a combination of the adsorption, desorption, and reaction effects. Despite the significant NH3-SCR activity, the presence of NH3 does not affect the binding of NOx on the various adsorption sites, as interpreted from the similar temperatures for NO2 desorption peaks with and without the presence of NH3 in the feed. A comparison of the NOx concentration profiles for various inlet compositions suggests that the NOx binding is primarily governed by the presence of H2, and the difference in the NOx concentration profiles is attributed to the onset of HC-SCR and NH3-SCR activity at different temperatures. The Ag/Mg-Al catalyst exhibits a high N2 selectivity during NH3-SCR and C3H6-SCR, with a negligible formation of N2O. For a wide temperature range, the NO2/NOx ratio is found to be more than 0.5 during the adsorption-desorption experiments. Thus, the catalyst can be placed upstream of a SCR catalyst and/or a DPF, thus increasing their performance and reducing their loading requirements. Moreover, the data on cumulative NOx adsorption and reduction for various reductant combinations convincingly show that the present catalyst can perform the dual role of a PNA and SCR, thereby achieving low NOx emissions over a broad temperature range. coredata.dc:description: An Ag/MgO/ γ -Al2O3 catalyst is developed, which can perform the dual role of a passive NOx adsorber (PNA) at low temperatures and a NOx reduction catalyst at higher temperatures. The effect of H2O and CO2, as well as various reductants such as H2, NH3, and C3H6 on its deNOx performance is investigated. The NOx storage is comparable to that obtained by Pd-based PNAs, and occurs through a spillover mechanism. The presence of H2 remarkably increases the low-temperature NOx adsorption and binding strength, and is attributed to the significant formation of nitrates as opposed to the predominant formation of nitrites in the absence of H2. Moreover, the positive effect of H2 is not related to the H2-SCR activity of the catalyst or an enhancement in the NO oxidation activity. C3H6 inhibits NOx storage, but the presence of H2 promotes it considerably. A significantly high NH3-SCR activity with negligible N2O formation is measured at 150 °C, while C3H6-SCR activity is exhibited at higher temperatures. However, the presence of NH3 does not affect the binding of NOx on the various adsorption sites, which is primarily governed by the presence of H2.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of gas composition on the NOx adsorption and reduction activity of a dual-function Ag/MgO/ γ -Al2O3 catalyst
